case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Coal Shipments P Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1494 to 1498 of 1971 were filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 15, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 13 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1494 to 1498 of 1971. Appeals by special leave, from the judgment and order dated November 15, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 13 of 1963.

facts.text: The appeals were filed by the Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal against the judgment of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: T. Desai, S. K. Aiyar, R. N. Sachthey and B. D. Sharma, for the appellant  in all the appeals . A. Palkhivala, T. A. Ramachandran and D. N. Gupta, for the respondent  in all the appeals . The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Khanna, J. This judgment would dispose of five Civil Appeal Nos. 1494 to 1498 of 1971 by Special Leave filed by the ,Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal against the judgment of Calcutta High Court whereby the question referred to that ,Court under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  hereinafter referred to as the Act  for five assessment years was answered in favour of the assessee-respondent-Coal Shipments  P  Ltd.

facts.text: The matter relates to assessment years 1951-52, 1952-53, 1953-54, 1954-55 and 1955-56 with corresponding accounting years ending on 31-3-1951, 31-3-1952, 31-3-1953, 31-3-1954 and 31-3-1955.

anchor.surface_text: The matter relates to the assessment years 1951-52, 1952-53, 1953-54, 1954-55 and 1955-56, the companyresponding accounting years for which ended on 31-3-1951, 31-3-1952, 31-3-1953, 31-3-1954 and 31-3-1955 respectively.

facts.text: The respondent was one of the companies which exported coal from India to Burma before the Second World War.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was one of the companypanies which exported companyl from India to Burma before the Second World War. Amongst the other exporters were Messrs. Karamchand Thaper Bros. Ltd., Messrs Macheill Barry Ltd., Messrs. Andrew Yule Co. Ltd. and Messrs. R. V. Low Co. Ltd.

facts.text: After cessation of hostilities in 1946, export of coal to Burma resumed.

anchor.surface_text: After the cessation of hostilities in 1946, it became possible to resume the export of companyl to Burma.

facts.text: Members of the coal trade in Bengal formed Coal Exporters and Charters Association.

anchor.surface_text: In order to overcome the difficulties in the companyduct of the trade following the war, the members of the companyl trade in Bengal formed an association styled Coal Exporters and Charters Association.

facts.text: Respondent and M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. were major members of the association.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany as well as M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. were two of the major members 1091 of the said association.

facts.text: In 1946, respondent resumed coal export to Burma; H.V. Low expressed intention to export.

anchor.surface_text: When M s. H. V. Low Co. learnt of the, resumption of companyl export to Burma by the respondent in 1946, they also expressed intention to export companyl to Burma.

facts.text: Respondent and M/s. H.V. Low Co. Ltd. entered into a verbal agreement: Low not to export coal to Burma, assist respondent in procuring coal, respondent pay Rs.1/- per ton (later Rs.1.5/-) of coal shipped.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the two companypanies came to an understanding and arrived at a mutual arrangement or agreement on the following lines - M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. would number export companyl to Burma during the subsistence of the agreement. M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. would assist the respondent in procuring companyl for shipment to Burma. The respondent would carry on the companyl shipping business and pay M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. Rs. 151- per ton  subsequently raised to Rs. 1-5- per ton  of companyl shipped to Burma.

facts.text: Last shipment of coal under the arrangement was made in June 1954; arrangement ended automatically.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondent, the last shipment of companyl under the above arrangement was made in June, 1954 after which the arrangement came to an end automatically and the Government of Burma made some other arrangement for its companyl requirement.

The assessee respondent claimed to have made the following payments to M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. or their numberinees in pursuance of the aforesaid agreement during the period of five accounting years from 1st April, 1950 to March 31,1955- Rs. 1951-52 91,149 1952-53 . 1,77,898 1953-54 3,03,631 1954-55 2,32,355 1955-56 79,917

facts.text: The amounts were taxed in the hands of M/s. H.V. Low Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The amounts mentioned above were taxed in the hands of M s. V. Low Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed the payments as no written agreement and possibly to secure monopoly, not for business purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer held that the expenditures claimed companyld number be allowed, as there was numberwritten agreement in proof of the alleged arrangement and it was number possible to say that the payments were made for the purpose of the assessees business. The Income-tax Officer further held that even assuming that the payments were made to keep off M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. from the Burma trade, they were payments to secure a monopoly and were number, therefore, allowable as revenue expenditure.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO's order.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal upheld the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal found discrepancy in facts, required affidavit from Sir Walter Michelmore, Director of Managing Agents of respondent, who was examined orally; remanded to ITO who investigated and reported.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came up in second appeal before the Income- tax Appellate Tribunal, the Tribunal found that there was some 1092 discrepancy in the facts stated on behalf of the assessee and the Revenue. The Tribunal thereupon required the respondent companypany to swear- an affidavit in support of the facts relied upon by it. In pursuance thereof, Sir Walter Michelmore, Director of Managing Agents of the respondent companypany filed an affidavit. Sir Walter was also examined orally before the Tribunal. The case was thereupon remanded to the Income-tax Officer to verify the facts as stated in the affidavit of Sir Walter and report back to the Tribunal. The Income-tax Officer after making further investigation submitted his report.

facts.text: Tribunal held payments made per agreement for business purpose, no monopoly acquired, revenue expenditure allowable under section 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: Both the questions were answered in favour of the respondent by the Tribunal. It was held that the payments were made in pursuance of the alleged agreement in the interest of the respondents trade. The version of the respondent about its agreement with M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. was accepted. ... The expenditures in question were, in the opinion of the Tribunal, attributable to revenue and number to capital. As such, they were held to be permissible expenditures under section 10 2   xv  of the Act.

facts.text: On Revenue's application, question referred to High Court: whether payments capital nature not allowable u/s 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: On application filed by the Revenue, the following question was referred to the High Court Whether on. the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the payments made by the assessee to M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. or their numberinees were of a capital nature and as such number allowable under section 10 2   xv  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 ?

facts.text: Before High Court, agreement and payments not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed before the High Court that there was an. agreement between the respondent and M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. on terms stated by the respondent and that the payments in question were made under that agreement.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered question in negative, in favour of assessee on 15 November 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was held entitled to claim the deduction of the expenditures under section 10  2   xv  of the Act. In the result, the question referred to the Court was answered in the negative and in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no merit in appeals, dismissed them; Tribunal findings binding.

anchor.surface_text: We have heard Mr. Desai on behalf of the appellant and Mr. Palkhiwala on behalf of the respondent and are of the opinion that there is numbermerit in these appeals. ... The above findings of fact are, for the purpose of these proceedings, binding upon the appellant and companysequently numberattempt was made either in the High Court or in this Court to assail them.

facts.text: During pendency of appeals, respondent's name changed to Heilgers Investment Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeals, the name of the respondent was changed to Heilgers Investment Ltd.

facts.text: Arrangement was verbal, temporary, terminable at will, no enduring advantage.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the arrangement arrived at verbally between the respondent and M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. was a temporary measure liable to be terminated ,at will and the respondent companypany did number derive any advantage of an enduring character by such payments.

facts.text: Payments related to quantum of coal shipped, not fixed sum.

anchor.surface_text: Further. as the payment was related to the quantum of companyl shipped to Burma in the companyrse of trading activity and was number companynected with the capital value of the assets, the payment, Mr. Palkhiwala submits, should be companysidered to be revenue expenditure.

facts.text: H.V. Low assisted in procuring coal and abstained from exporting during agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has found that the amounts in question were paid by the respondent to M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. in pursuance of the agreement according to which M s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. were to assist the respondent in procuring companyl for shipment to Burma and were themselves number to export companyl to Burma during the subsistence of the agreement.

facts.text: No monopoly rights acquired by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It was further held that the respondent companypany did number acquire any monopoly rights to carry on Burma trade and the impugned payments were made to carry on the trade in a more facile and profitable manner.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is companysiderable force in Mr. Palkhiwalas submission. Judicial decisions have, from time to time, laid down some broad principles in order to determine whether an expenditure is of a capital nature or revenue nature. Despite the enunciation of those principles, it is number always easy to decide the question in the companytext of the circumstances of an individual case.

concepts.interpretation: Expenditure is capital if made to acquire enduring benefit or advantage for the trade, not terminable at will, related to fixed capital or once and for all; revenue if related to trading operations, circulating capital, recurring, no enduring advantage. Here, verbal temporary arrangement terminable at will, payments per ton shipped, no monopoly or enduring benefit, hence revenue.

anchor.surface_text: There are some other tests like those of fixed capital and circulating capital for determining the nature of the expenditure. An item of disbursement can be regarded as capital expenditure when it is referable to fixed capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's factual findings on agreement, payments, no monopoly, temporary nature verified and unchallenged, binding on higher courts.

holdings.text: The payment made to M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. for assistance to the respondent in procuring coal for shipment to Burma was an item of revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the payment is concerned which was made to M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. for assistance to the respondent in procuring coal for shipment to Burma, it was admittedly an item of revenue expenditure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted by parties; part of agreement for business assistance in trade.

holdings.text: That part of the payment which was made because of M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. having agreed not to export coal to Burma during the subsistence of the agreement constituted revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: The controversy between the parties has centered on the point as to whether that part of the payment which was made because, of M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. having agreed not to export coal to Burma during the subsistence of the agreement constituted capital expenditure or revenue expenditure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arrangement verbal, temporary, terminable at will; no enduring benefit; transitory advantage; payments per ton shipped, related to trading operations.

holdings.text: An enduring benefit or advantage should not be so transitory and ephemeral that it can be terminated at any time at the volition of any of the parties; otherwise the word 'enduring' would be meaningless.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accede to this contention because we find that the arrangement between the respondent and M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. was not for any fixed term but could be terminated at any time at the volition of any of the parties. Although an enduring benefit need not be of an everlasting character, it should not, at the same time, be so transitory and ephemeral that it can be terminated at any time at the volition of any of the parties. Any other view would have the effect of rendering the word enduring to be meaningless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarifies scope of 'enduring benefit' doctrine from Atherton; terminable at will lacks endurance; distinguishes perpetual from non-ephemeral.

holdings.text: The payments made by the assessee to M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. or their nominees were not of a capital nature and as such allowable under section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on. the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the payments made by the assessee to M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. or their nominees were of a capital nature and as such not allowable under section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: No monopoly or enduring advantage acquired; temporary arrangement; variable payments tied to shipments, not fixed capital; follows Tribunal/High Court; applies capital vs revenue tests.

holdings.text: The payments made to M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. were related to the actual shipment of coal in the course of the trading activities of the respondent and had no relation to the capital value of the assets.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the above, we find that the payments made to M/s. V. Low Co. Ltd. were related to the actual shipment of coal in the course of the trading activities of the respondent and had no relation to the capital value of the assets.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Variable per ton shipped, akin to circulating capital and trading ops; analogous to Travancore Sugars where % profits revenue.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals consequently fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of tests confirms revenue nature; no merit in Revenue's case.

precedents.citation: Abdul Kayoom v. Ccommissioner of Income-tax 44 I.T.R. 68

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Kayoom v. Ccommissioner of Income-tax 1  that numbere of the tests  laid down in various authorities  is either exhaustive or universal. Each case must depend on its own facts, and a close similarity between one case and another is number enough because even a single significant detail may alter the entire aspect.

precedents.cited_proposition: none of the tests laid down in various authorities is either exhaustive or universal; each case depends on its own facts; avoid matching colours of cases

precedents.citation: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd. 10 T.C. 155

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd. 2 -, Lord Cave, L.C. laid down the following criterion which has been referred to in most of the subsequent cases - But when an expenditure is made, number only once and for all, but with a view to bringing into existence an asset or an advantage for the enduring benefit of a trade, I think that there is very good reason  in the absence of the special circumstances leading to an oppo- site companyclusion  for treating such an expenditure as properly attributable number to revenue but to capital.

precedents.case_name: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: expenditure made not only once and for all but to bring into existence an asset or advantage for enduring benefit of trade is capital
precedents.cited_holding: payment for pension fund created enduring benefit, hence capital

precedents.citation: Robert Addie and Sons Collieries Limited v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 8 T.C. 671

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Robert Addie and Sons Collieries Limited v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1 , Lord President Clyde gave the following test-- It is necessary accordingly to attend to the true nature of the expenditure, and to ask ones self the question, is it a part of the Companys working expenses ?-is it expenditure laid out as part of the process of profit earning ?--or, on the other hand, is it a capital outlay ?-is it expenditure necessary for the acquisition of property or of rights of a permanent character, the process of which is a companydition of carrying on its trade at all

precedents.case_name: Robert Addie & Sons Collieries Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: is the expenditure part of working expenses/process of profit earning or capital outlay for acquisition of property/rights of permanent character?

precedents.citation: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 27 I.T.R. 34

anchor.surface_text: The expression once and for all used in the dictum laid down in Athertons case  supra  was referred to by Bhagwati, J. speaking for this Court in the case of Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 2  and it was observed that the expression was used to denote an expenditure which is made once and for all for procuring an enduring benefit to the business as distinguished from a recurring expenditure in the nature of operational expenses.

precedents.case_name: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. CIT, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: 'once and for all' denotes expenditure for enduring benefit vs recurring operational; character by true nature of asset acquired, not lump sum/instalments; permanent/enduring relative, not perpetual

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Taxes v. Nchanga Consolidated Copper Mines Ltd. 58 I.T.R. 241

anchor.surface_text: Such a companytention indeed was repelled by the Judicial Committee in the case of Commissioner of Taxes v. Nchanga Consolidated Copper Mines Ltd. 1 . The respondent companypany in that case together with two other companypanies- Rhokana Corporation Ltd. and Bancroft Mines Ltd. formed a group for carrying on the business of companyper mining.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Taxes v. Nchanga Consolidated Copper Mines Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: payment to compensate rival for ceasing production for 1 year is revenue, not for enduring benefit as it exhausts within the period
precedents.cited_holding: compensation to Bancroft to stop production for 12 months is allowable revenue deduction

precedents.citation: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. 27 I.T.R. 34

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. 1  the appellant companypany acquired from the Government of Assam a lease of certain lime-stone quarries for a period of twenty years for the purpose of carrying on the manufacture of cement In addition to the rent and royalties, the appellant agreed to pay the lessor annually a sum of Rs. 5,000/- during the whole period of the lease as a protection fee

precedents.case_name: Assam Bengal Cement Co. Ltd. v. CIT, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: annual protection fee for 20-year lease period to prevent others getting licences creates enduring advantage, hence capital
precedents.cited_holding: annual payments of Rs.5000 and 35000 as protection fee held capital expenditure

precedents.citation: Travancore Sugars and Chemicals Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala 62 I.T.R. 566

anchor.surface_text: The dictum laid down by this Court in Travancore Sugars and Chemicals Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala 2  in the circumstances is attracted. The appellant companypany in that case was to take over the assets of sugar manufacturing companycern, a distillery and a tincture factory of the Government of Travancore.

precedents.case_name: Travancore Sugars & Chemicals Ltd. v. CIT, Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: payment as % of annual net profits, indefinite period, related to trading profits not capital value/assets, not tied to fixed sum, is revenue
precedents.cited_holding: 10% of annual net profits to govt under agreement for taking over assets is revenue expenditure

precedents.citation: Henriksen Inspector of Taxes v. Grafton, Hotel Ltd. 11 I.T.R. 10

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Desai has referred to the following observations of Lord Greens in Henriksen  Inspector of Taxes  v. Grafton, Hotel Ltd. 1  - It appears to me that there can be numberdifference in principle between a payment out- and-out for monopoly value and a payment in respect of a term.

precedents.cited_proposition: annual instalments for licence monopoly value for term are capital like lease premium, despite appearance of periodicity
precedents.cited_holding: monopoly value payments in instalments for 3-year licence term are capital

anchor.surface_text: is it expenditure laid out as part of the process of profit earning ?--or, on the other hand, is it a capital outlay ?-is it expenditure necessary for

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accede to this contention because we find that the arrangement between the respondent and M/s. H. V. Low Co. Ltd. was not for any fixed term but could be terminated at any time at the volition of any of the parties. Although an enduring benefit need not be of an everlasting character, it should not, at the same time, be so transitory and ephemeral that it can be terminated at any time at the volition of any of the parties. Any other view would have the effect of rendering the word enduring to be meaningless.
The appeals companysequently fail and are dismissed with companyts.
